docs.lead_paragraph: In June 1969, Tobe Carey and the other members of his family commune, the True Light Beavers, moved here to the town that would provide the inspiration, if not the setting, for the famous festival bearing its name. "This is my brother Marty and his wife, Susan," Mr. Carey said, pointing at two nude figures sitting in a field with a group of unclothed others, their young images displayed this morning on a video screen in his attic studio. "And there's Abbie Hoffman," he added, identifying a bearded man with his bare buttocks to the camera.

headline.main: Woodstock Nation, and Address; Social Conscience and Freedom Shine for Those Who Stayed

docs.lead_paragraph: Roy Rogers's horse seemed to come thundering down the halls of Congress last month: the word on all lips was trigger, not so famously used in politics since Nelson Rockefeller called Barry Goldwater trigger-happy. When you pull a trigger, a gun goes off. From the Middle Dutch trecken, "to pull" (same root as trek, as in "Star Trek"), the English word began in 1621 as tricker, meaning "the lever that springs a trap"; it soon became the name for the small steel catch that releases the hammer or firing pin of a gun when drawn, pressed, pulled or -- to use the verb my sergeant preferred -- squeezed.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a letter to Senator Bob Dole, governors from both parties said today that they opposed an important element of the health care plan offered by Senate Republicans because it sets strict limits on Federal spending for Medicaid. The plan, an alternative to the proposals of President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, seeks to widen access to health care without raising taxes. In addition, at a news conference here, the leaders of the National Governors' Association called on Congress to pass health care legislation this year even if the bill is less sweeping than the President's proposal.

headline.main: GOVERNORS OPPOSE KEY DOLE PROPOSAL ON A HEALTH PLAN
headline.kicker: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE STATES

docs.lead_paragraph: A sharp battle broke out yesterday over a television advertisement that accuses Pizza Hut of hypocrisy for opposing a proposed requirement that employers buy health insurance for their workers in this country while providing such insurance for its own workers overseas. The Health Care Reform Project, a coalition of groups that say employers should help pay for insurance, showed the commercial to reporters, along with a report criticizing Pizza Hut, a division of Pepsico, and McDonald's for lobbying against the employer mandate. But the commercial, which mentions only Pizza Hut, will not be shown outside the Congressional hearing room where the coalition's news conference was held because Pizza Hut persuaded four Washington television stations not to broadcast it.

headline.main: Health Insurance Ad Criticizes Pizza Hut

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today began a vigorous and probably final crusade to sell his national health insurance program to voters and Congress, flying to rural Pennsylvania to assert that the program would be a boon to the middle class and that its critics were all but liars. Standing in shirt sleeves, flushed in the vapory heat, Mr. Clinton punched the air and pounded his lectern as he argued, again and again, that working people were the only ones who would suffer if his plan to guarantee health insurance to everyone did not become law.

headline.main: Clinton, on the Stump, Opens a Final Health Care Push
headline.kicker: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE CAMPAIGN

docs.lead_paragraph: A sharp battle broke out today over workers' health insurance, pitting Pizza Hut against Senator Edward M. Kennedy and a coalition supporting President Clinton's proposal for universal health insurance. The Health Care Reform Project, a coalition of unions and other groups that would require employers to help pay for insurance, held a news conference here to release a report and show a television commercial accusing the company of hypocrisy on health care. The report said Pizza Hut and McDonald's paid for workers' coverage abroad while fighting legislation that would make them do the same in the United States.

headline.kicker: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE EMPLOYER MANDATE

docs.lead_paragraph: Companies Microsoft reached an agreement with the Justice Department under which the company will change some of its business practices to end a four-year antitrust battle on charges that it unfairly tried to stifle competition. [ Page 1. ] The Justice Department approved AT&T's $12.6 billion takeover of McCaw Cellular Communications, setting the stage for the nation's biggest long-distance carrier to become the largest operator of wireless communications as well. [ 37. ] A key to the Federated Department Stores bid to merge with R. H. Macy was the work of Ronald W. Tysoe, Federated's vice chairman and chief financial officer, who spearheaded the deal that will form the country's largest department-store chain. [ 37. ] Investors fled the stocks of computer chip makers after Texas Instruments predicted that the runaway growth in chip sales in the first half of the year would slow. [ 37. ] Hallmark Cards plans to market its Shoebox unit's characters to outside manufacturers, hoping the characters will adorn men's ties, boxer shorts, barbecue aprons, watches and clocks, and also star in a comic strip and an animated television series. [ 37. ] U S West plans to pay $1.2 billion to acquire Wometco Cable and Georgia Cable Television, which together control 65 percent of the market in metropolitan Atlanta. [ 39. ] Shares of Litton Industries rose after the company agreed to pay $83 million to settle a lawsuit that contended it had overcharged the Government for computer services. [ 39. ] Pacific Bell hopes to begin building a customer base for a new wireless service by seeking regulatory approval to resell cellular phone service delivered by other companies. [ 39. ] Pizza Hut persuaded some TV stations not to run an ad that contends it was hypocritical for paying for workers' health insurance abroad while opposing U.S. employer mandates. [ 9. ] Markets Nasdaq's huge computer system passed out. Before frantic engineers could revive the system and steady its pulse, more than two and a half hours had elapsed. [ 37. ] The stock market moved mostly higher in a sluggish session highlighted by options-related trading and a sharp selloff in semiconductor shares. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 14.56 points, to close at 3,757.81. [ 38. ] The bond market failed to extend Thursday's strong rally, ending the day with little change after giving up its early gains. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond edged up to 7.54 percent, from 7.53 percent on Thursday. [ 42. ] The dollar fell against the Japanese yen, ending a two-day rally, after Japan said its trade surplus with the United States had surged 43 percent in June. [ 43. ] Cocoa jumped to its highest price in four years and coffee resumed its climb. [ 43. ] The Economy Industrial production rose 0.5 percent in June, as hot weather forced a surge in utility output, the Government said. In another report, the Commerce Department said business inventories rose 1.1 percent in May, the largest increase in nearly seven years. [ 42. ] Your Money Money managers and analysts are raising caution flags about real estate investment trusts amid a flood of new issues. [ 35. ] Swindlers are prowling on-line computer systems and the Internet, hunting for unwary investors. [ 35. ] The new I.R.S. rules on donations to charities pose some tricky issues. [ 35. ] The financial services group of equity funds eked out a gain during the first half of 1994, despite rising interest rates. [ 35. ] More companies are trying to capture the elderly market by offering discounts and special deals to older people. [ 36. ]

docs.lead_paragraph: YESTERDAY Television commercials became a source of dispute in the fight over universal coverage and the employer mandate. President Clinton campaigned for his measure in Pennsylvania, and members of Congress focused on the extent of coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Litton Industries' shares rose today after the company agreed to pay a total of $86 million to settle a lawsuit that had accused it of overcharging the Government for computer services. The move eliminated what the company had estimated to be a $650 million potential liability.

headline.main: Whistle-Blower Suit Settled, Litton Shares Move Higher
